title: Algebraic Expressions
description:
Algebraic Expressions
Algebraic Expressions are obtained when we combine constants and variables using arithmetic operators.
Ex: x + y, 3x + 2
Learn more about Algebraic Expressions and its Terms.
author: Anurag Chaturvedi

title: वर्ण
description:
हिन्दी भाषा में प्रयुक्त सबसे छोटी इकाई वर्ण कहलाती है। जैसे-अ, आ, इ, ई, उ, ऊ, क्, ख् आदि।
भाषा की मूल ध्वनियों के क्रमबद्ध व्यवस्थित समूह को वर्णमाला (Alphabet) कहते हैं।
हिंदी वर्णमाला के समस्त वर्णों को व्याकरण में दो भागों में विभक्त किया गया है- स्वर और व्यंजन!

स्वर : जिन वर्णों का उच्चारण करते समय साँस, कण्ठ, तालु आदि स्थानों से बिना रुके हुए निकलती है, उन्हें 'स्वर' कहा जाता है।
अ, आ, इ, ई, उ, ऊ, ऋ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ, ऑ

व्यंजन : जिन वर्णों का उच्चारण करते समय साँस कण्ठ, तालु आदि स्थानों से रुककर निकलती है, उन्हें 'व्यंजन' कहा जाता है। प्राय: व्यंजनों का उच्चारण स्वर की सहायता से किया जाता है।
क, ख, ग, घ, ङ (क़, ख़, ग़)
च, छ, ज, झ, ञ (ज़)
ट, ठ, ड, ढ, ण, (ड़, ढ़)
त, थ, द, ध, न
प, फ, ब, भ, म (फ़)
य, र, ल, व
श, श़, ष, स, ह
संयुक्त व्यंजन- क्ष, त्र, ज्ञ, श्र
author: Archana Tiwari

title: Conjunction
description:
Conjunction
A conjunction is a word that connects other words, phrases, clauses and even sentences. It makes it possible to connect complex, relevant sentence and skip the choppiness of numerous short sentences.
Examples: and, but, because, etc.


Types of Conjunctions

a. Coordination Conjunction
It is used to link two words, phrases or clauses of the same same structure. It is the most commonly used and is 7 in seven number: AND, NOR, OR, FOR, BUT, SO & YET.

b. Correlative Conjunction
It joins two essential parts of a sentence to compare or contrast words or ideeas in sentences. The most commonly used examples are: NEITHER - NOR, EITHER - OR, NOT ONLY - BUT - ALSO, WHETHER, etc.

c. Subordinating Conjunction
It joins two clauses of dissimilar structure of unequal imprtance, this is usually the case with independent and non-independent clauses. The most commonly used examples are: BECAUSE, SINCE, ALTHOUGH, BEFORE, UNTIL, UNLESS, etc.
author: Akanksha Singh

title: Force
description:
Force
Any push or pull on an object is called Force. SI unit of Force is Newton(N).
1kg.m/sec^2 = 1N

Balanced Force
When two forces are applied on an object and the resultant forcce is 0, then we can say that the applied forces are equal or 'balanced'.
author: Anshuman Tiwari

title: Adverbs
description:
Adverb
It is a word or phrase that qualifies an adjective, verb, or other adverb or a word group.

Kinds of Adverb:
a. Adverb of Manner
b. Adverb of Place
c. Adverb of Time
d. Adverb of Frequency
e. Adverb of Degree
f. Interrogative Adverb
g. Relative Adverb
h. Adverb of Affirmation/Negation
author: Chandan Srivastava

title: HTML Basics
description:
HTML stands for Hyper Text Markup Language. It is a case-insensitive language. We can write HTML code in any text editor like Notepad++.
'HTML' is the first tag used in an HTML document. It contains 'HEAD' and 'BODY' tags.
In 'HEAD' tag, we use 'TITLE' tag to give the page title.
In 'BODY' tag we put all the content that is needed to be displayed on the webpage. 'BODY' tag has many attributes. Ex: 'bgcolor' which is used to set the background color of the webpage.

An HTML document is saved with the extension 'htm' or 'html'. Browsers are used to open HTML webpages.
Learn more about HTML structure.

title: HTML Tables
description:
Tables are used to display data in a comprehensive manner.
In HTML we create tables using 'TABLE' tag. This tag has several attributes, ex: border which is used to set table border in pixels.
'TR' tag is used to create rows.
'TD' is used to create cells in table row.
Learn more about HTML TABLE structure.
author: Imtiaz Hussain

title: HTML Forms
description:
HTML Form is an object which is used to collect data from the user and send it to backend. 'FORM' tag is used to create a form in HTML.

'INPUT' tag is used to take input from the user in different formats. Its attribute 'type' defines the type of data that the user can enter.
For example: type='text' defines that the user can enter single line text/string values, type='submit' will show a submit button, etc.
author: Imtiaz Hussain

title: Addition
description:
Addition
When we add two or more numbers, it is called addition. Ex: 2 + 3 = 5, here '2' & '3' are addends and '5' is sum.

Properties of Addition
a. Property of '0': the sum of any number and zero is the number itself.
b. Property of '1': the sum of any number and 1 is the successor of the number.
c. Order Property / Commutative Property: when we add addens in any order the of addition remains same.
d. Grouping Property / Associative Property: The property that states that the way addends are grouped does not change the result of the addition.
author: Priya Singh

title: Bubble Wrap Painting
description:
Learn Bubble Wrap Painting

Materials Required:
a. Bubble Wrap sheet
b. Scissor
c. Paint Brush
d. Water Color / Poster Color
author: Sushma Srivastava

title: समास
description:
समास
दो या दो से अधिक शब्दों का परस्पर सम्बन्ध बताने वाले शब्दों के मेल से बने एक स्वतन्त्र शब्द को समास कहते हैं। उदाहरण 'दया का सागर' का सामासिक शब्द बनता है 'दयासागर'।
समास से निर्मित शब्द समस्तपद कहलाता है।
समास में दो पद (शब्द) होते हैं। पहले पद को पूर्वपद और दूसरे पद को उत्तरपद कहते हैं। जैसे-गंगाजल।गंगा+जल, जिसमें गंगा पूर्व पद है,और जल उत्तर पद।

जब समस्त पद के सभी पद अलग - अलग किय जाते हैं उसे समास-विग्रह कहते हैं।

समास के छ: भेद हैं-
तत्पुरुष समास- वह समास, जिसका उत्तरपद या अंतिम पद प्रधान हो। अर्थात् प्रथम पद गौण हो और उत्तरपद की प्रधानता हो। जैसे- राजकुमार
कर्मधारय समास- जिस समास में पूर्वपद विशेषण और उत्तरपद विशेष्य हो, कर्मधारय समास कहलाता है। इसमें भी उत्तरपद प्रधान होता है; जैसे-कालीमिर्च
अव्ययीभाव समास- जिस समास में पूर्वपद अव्यय हो, अव्ययीभाव समास कहलाता है। यह वाक्य में क्रिया-विशेषण का कार्य करता है; जैसे- यथास्थान
द्विगु समास- जिस समास में पूर्वपद संख्यावाचक हो, द्विगु समास कहलाता है। जैसे- नवरत्न
द्वन्द्व समास- जिस समास में पूर्वपद और उत्तरपद दोनों ही प्रधान हों अर्थात् अर्थ की दृष्टि से दोनों का स्वतन्त्र अस्तित्व हो और उनके मध्य संयोजक शब्द का लोप हो तो द्वन्द्व समास कहलाता है; जैसे- माता-पिता
बहुव्रीहि समास- जिस समास में दोनों पदों के माध्यम से एक विशेष (तीसरे) अर्थ का बोध होता है, बहुव्रीहि समास कहलाता है; जैसे- महात्मा
author: Meeta Srivastava

title: Geometry
description:
Fundamental Concepts of Geometry

a. Point: A point has no length, no widt and no thickness, but only position.
b. Line: A line has only length. It has no end point.
c. Line Segment: A line segment is a part of a line and has a fixed length. It has two fixed end point.
d. Ray: A ray is a line segment extended endlessly in one direction. A ray has only one end point.
author: Priya Singh

title: मात्रा
description:
मात्रा स्वर का ही एक रूप होता है। जो स्वर का ही प्रतिनिधित्व करता है मात्राओं की संख्या ग्यारह होती है।

अनुस्वार शब्द: पसंद, गंदा
अनुनासिक शब्द: गाँव, मुँह
विसर्ग शब्द: चक्षुः, मतिः
आगत शब्द: डॉक्टर, बॉल
author: Renu Arya

title: Fraction
description:
Fraction
When we divide a whole into equal parts, each part is called a fraction. Ex: 1/2 (half), 1/3 (one-third), 1/4 (one-fourth), etc.

When writing a fraction, the denominator tells how many parts there are all together.
The numberator tells how many parts are counted.

Numerator: The top number in a fraction is called numerator.
Denominator: The bottom number in a fraction is called denominator.
author: Sangeeta Srivastava

title: Living Beings (Part 1)
description:
Living and Non-living Things

Non-living Things: Non-living things are things that were once alive or have never been alive.
These things do not need food, water and air.
These things do not have the ability to reproduce or give birth, grow and change on their own, and respond to changes in environment.

Living Things: Living Things are things that are alive.
They need food, water and air to stay alive.
They have the ability to reproduce or give birth, grow and change on their own, and respond to changes in environment.
author: Seema Mishra

title: Living Beings (Part 2)
description:
Feeding Plants and Animals

All living beings need food. Plants make their own food from carbon dioxide and water. Water is absorbed from the soil by the roots. Carbon dioxide comes from the air., which enters a plant through pores on the leaves.
Water + Carbon dioxide (in presence of sublight) gives Food.

All animals depend on plants for food. Some animals, like goats, cows and deer are plant-eaters. Other animals like tigers, lions and wolves are flesh-eaters. They eat the flesh of other animals. Even flesh-eaters depend on plants for food because they eat animals which eat plants.
Non-living thins do not need food.
author: Seema Mishra

title: Living Beings (Part 3)
description:
Breathing in Plants and Animals

All living beings breathe. They take in air and use the oxygen to produce energy. Inside the body of a living being, oxygen and food combine (join up) to produce energy. They also produce carbon dioxide and water vapour. Carbon dioxide and water vapour are thrown out by living beings together with the unused part of air.
Oxygen + Food gives Carbon dioxide + Water Vapour + Energy

Different animals use different parts of their body to breathe. We take in and throw out air through our nose. So do many other animals, like dogs, cats, cows, tigers and lions. Birds breathe through nostrils on or above their beak. Frogs and earthworms breathe thorugh their skin. Insects breathe through holes on their sides. Fish take in oxygen from water. Their gills help them do this.
author: Seema Mishra

title: Natural Resources
description:
Natural Resources

Resources are things we can use, for example, money, machines and land. All the natural things we use are our natural resources. Air, water, soil, rocks, fuels, plants and animals are all natural resources.

Forests and Grasslands
Forests and grasslands help us in many ways. They give us wood and grasses to make paper. They give us timber, firewood and medicines. People graze famrs animals on grasslands and in forests. They also collect fruits, roots, honey, bamboo and other things from them.
Forests and grasslands are the natural home of wild animals. They maintain the balance of gases in the air. They also protect the soil from erosion (being carried away). The roots of plants hold the soil firmly and stop it from being wasted away or blown away.
author: Seema Mishra

title: For Loop in QBASIC
description:
For Loop
Loops allows a specified group of statements to be executed a certain number of times while certain condition is true. For Loop is used to execute the set of statements repeatedly for a given number of times.
Learn more about For Loop with the help of a program.
author: Sonal Srivastava

title: QBASIC Program
description:
Understand the basic structure of QBASIC program

- CLS: It is used to 'clear screen'.
- PRINT: It is used to display / print anything on output screen.
- END: It marks the end of the program.
- LET: It is used to declare variables.
author: Sonal Srivastava
